name: King's Indian Attack
description: A universal system for White. Set up with Nf3, g3, Bg2, d3, Nbd2 and e4 against almost anything.

move.explanation: Develop the king's knight first — the KIA way! This flexible move doesn't commit you to any particular pawn structure yet, and it fights for the center with a piece right away.
Black occupies the center with the queen's pawn. Black is claiming space and daring White to challenge it.
Begin the King's Indian Attack setup! You're going to build a solid fortress with g3, Bg2, d3, Nbd2, and e4. This same system works against almost any Black opening.
Black develops the knight to f6 — a natural and active square. Both sides are building up before the real fight begins.
Fianchetto the bishop! The bishop on g2 is the heart of the KIA — it controls the long diagonal and will support your future e4 pawn push powerfully.
Black plays solidly with e6, supporting d5 and preparing to develop the dark-squared bishop. This French Defense setup is one of the most common positions the KIA faces.
Castle early to get your king safe! In the KIA, you castle before pushing e4. Your king on g1 is very secure behind the fianchettoed bishop.
Black develops the bishop and prepares to castle. Both sides are completing their setups — the middlegame plans will soon be revealed.
The key KIA move — d3 supports the e4 pawn push and keeps the center flexible. Don't play d4 here! The plan is e4, not d4.
Black castles to safety. Both kings are now secure and the middlegame will decide the game.
Develop the queen's knight to d2 — the key KIA maneuver! From d2, the knight will go to f1 and then e3 or g3, perfectly coordinating with your e4 plan.
Black advances c5 to fight for queenside space. Now is the perfect time to unleash your plan!
The KIA's signature move! After all this careful preparation, e4 launches a powerful kingside attack. The e4 pawn opens lines and your pieces spring to life.
Black plays c5 right away, fighting for the center aggressively. This is the Sicilian setup with reversed colors.
Fianchetto the bishop regardless of Black's move order. The KIA setup is the same against everything — g3, Bg2, d3, Nbd2, e4.
Black develops the queen's knight, putting pressure on the d4 square. Black is building up actively.
Castle to safety — king first! Now continue with d3 and Nbd2 to complete the KIA formation before launching e4.
Black plays e5, creating a reversed King's Indian structure with pawns on c5, d5, and e5. Black has lots of space but the pieces are cramped behind the pawns.
Play d3 to solidify your position. In the KIA against ...c5/d5/e5, your plan is still e4 — but you need to choose the right moment.
Black develops the bishop solidly. Your plan continues: Nbd2, then e4 to crack open Black's center and activate your pieces.
Black also fianchettos! This leads to a fascinating battle of opposing bishops — your g2 bishop versus Black's g7 bishop.
Complete your fianchetto. When both sides fianchetto, the battle of the long diagonals becomes a central theme.
Black completes the fianchetto with Bg7. The two bishops stare at each other across the board — a key strategic battle is coming.
Castle right away. Your king is very safe behind the fianchettoed bishop, and now you can play d3 and Nbd2 to prepare e4.
Black develops the knight. Both sides are building up their positions systematically.
Play d3 — the KIA backbone move. This supports e4 and completes the setup. After Nbd2, you'll be ready to push e4 and attack.
Black castles into the same corner as you. Now Nbd2 followed by e4 will open up the game with your pieces perfectly placed.
Black plays the French setup with e6 and d5. This is one of the most important positions the KIA must handle — a very popular practical choice.
Complete the fianchetto. The KIA setup is perfect against the French structure — your e4 push will directly challenge Black's pawn center.
Black plays c5, the most active response in the French-style setup. Now Black controls lots of space but you have a great KIA attack coming.
Castle! King safety comes first before the attack. After d3 and Nbd2, you'll be perfectly placed to strike with e4.
Black develops the queen's knight, controlling d4. Now d3 and Nbd2 will complete the KIA setup.
Play d3 to complete the KIA formation. After Nbd2 and e4, the attack launches. Bobby Fischer won brilliantly from this exact setup!
Black develops the last minor piece. Now Nbd2 followed by e4 launches the famous KIA attack against the French structure.

plan.summary: Build the KIA setup: Nf3, g3, Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2 — then launch e4! This powerful system works against almost any Black opening. Once you play e4, the game opens up and your pieces spring to life for a kingside attack.

strategicGoals.description: Complete the KIA formation: Nf3, g3, Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2
Push e4 at the right moment to open the center
Use the e5 outpost and attack on the kingside with e4-e5
Route the queen's knight via Nbd2-f1-e3/g3 for maximum activity

plan.pawnStructureTarget: White: e4, d3, c2 — a solid, flexible center that supports kingside attack

pieceTargets.reasoning: The fianchettoed bishop supports e4, controls the long diagonal, and defends the king on g1
The Nbd2-f1-e3 maneuver is the signature KIA knight route — e3 controls d5, f5, and supports the e4 push
e4 is the engine of the KIA attack — it opens lines and creates kingside pressure

typicalPlans: After e4, push e5 to gain kingside space and attack with Nf3-h4 and f4
If Black exchanges exd3, recapture with the c-pawn to get doubled center pawns on d3 and e4 — very solid
Against the French setup (d5/e6/c5), e4 is especially powerful — push e5 and attack the castled king
commonMistakes: Playing d4 instead of d3 — in the KIA, you want d3 to support e4, not a Queen's Gambit setup
Developing the queen's knight to c3 instead of d2 — Nbd2 is crucial because the knight goes to f1-e3
Pushing e4 before completing the setup (O-O and Nbd2) — you'll be attacking without enough support
plan.historicalNote: The King's Indian Attack became famous when Bobby Fischer used it repeatedly in the 1960s — including his legendary win against Robert Byrne in 1956 and his victories with the system against many top players. Fischer loved the KIA because it could be played against almost any Black setup, making his preparation universal. It's a great weapon for players who want to avoid deep opening theory.

planLessons.title: The KIA Blueprint
planLessons.description: Every KIA game follows the same blueprint: Nf3, g3, Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2, then e4. It doesn't matter what Black plays — you follow this same plan every time. Learning ONE system you can use against everything is a superpower!

planLessons.title: The Key Move: d3, Not d4!
planLessons.description: In the KIA, you play d3 — not d4! This important difference is what makes it a KIA and not a Queen's Gambit. d3 supports the e4 push and keeps the position solid. d4 would be a completely different strategy.

planLessons.title: The Knight Maneuver: Nbd2-f1-e3
planLessons.description: In the KIA, your queen's knight doesn't go to c3 — it goes to d2, then f1, then e3 (or g3). From e3, it controls the key squares d5 and f5 and is perfectly placed to support the e4 attack. This maneuver is the KIA's secret weapon!

planLessons.title: The e4 Push — The KIA's Punch
planLessons.description: After completing your setup, e4 is the move that starts the real game! It challenges Black's center and opens lines for your attack. When you can push e5 too, Black's kingside becomes very vulnerable.

planLessons.title: Don't Put the Knight on c3!
planLessons.description: In the KIA, the queen's knight goes to d2 — not c3! If you play Nc3, the knight blocks the c-pawn and can't use the f1-e3 route. The Nbd2 maneuver is what makes the KIA work.

planQuizzes.prompt: You've played Nf3, g3, and Bg2. What should you do next?

choices.text: O-O — castle to safety first, then play d3 and Nbd2
d4 — play a Queen's Gambit instead

planQuizzes.explanation: Castle first! In the KIA, the correct order is Nf3, g3, Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2 — then e4. Your king needs to be safe before you push e4 and open up the position.

planQuizzes.prompt: You've castled and played d3. Where should the queen's knight go?

choices.text: d2 — then f1, then e3: the KIA knight maneuver
c3 — the most natural development square

planQuizzes.explanation: Nbd2 is correct! From d2, the knight goes to f1 and then e3. From e3, it perfectly supports the e4 push and controls the key squares d5 and f5. Nc3 would block the c-pawn and miss this important maneuver.

planQuizzes.prompt: You've just played e4. Black has pawns on c5 and d5. What is your next plan?

choices.text: Push e5 to gain kingside space and attack Black's knight on f6
Play d4 to also push the d-pawn

planQuizzes.explanation: After e4, push e5! This gains kingside space, attacks the f6 knight (which must move), and opens lines for a kingside attack. The bishop on g2 helps control the center while your pieces swarm the kingside.

theoryLessons.title: KIA vs French Setup (A07)
theoryLessons.description: The most famous KIA line is against the French: 1.Nf3 d5 2.g3 e6 3.Bg2 c5 4.O-O Nc6 5.d3. Bobby Fischer used this to crush opponents at the highest level. After Nbd2, e4, e5 — the attack is brutal!

theoryLessons.title: KIA vs Sicilian Setup
theoryLessons.description: When Black plays ...c5 and ...Nc6 without d5, the position resembles a reversed Sicilian. White still follows the same KIA plan: d3, Nbd2, e4. But here you might push e5 or keep central tension longer.

theoryLessons.title: The Knight Route: d2-f1-e3
theoryLessons.description: The queen's knight takes a unique path in the KIA: Nb1-d2-f1-e3. This maneuver takes more moves than Nc3, but the knight on e3 is far more powerful — it supports e4, controls d5 and f5, and coordinates perfectly with the bishop on g2.

theoryLessons.title: KIA: Fianchetto vs Fianchetto (A07)
theoryLessons.description: When Black also fianchettos with ...g6 and ...Bg7, the game becomes a battle of the long diagonals. Both bishops stare at each other. White's e4 push is still the key plan — open lines and the better-placed pieces will win.

theoryQuizzes.prompt: This is the KIA vs French setup. What is White's NEXT move?

choices.text: Nbd2 — the key knight maneuver before e4
e4 — launch the attack right now
Nc3 — develop the knight to a central square

theoryQuizzes.explanation: Nbd2 first! You need to complete the setup before pushing e4. After Nbd2, the knight will go to f1 and then e3, perfectly supporting the e4 push. Playing e4 immediately without Nbd2 leaves the center under-supported.

theoryQuizzes.prompt: The King's Indian Attack setup (Nf3, g3, Bg2) works best against which of these Black setups?

choices.text: Almost any Black setup — that's the beauty of the KIA!

theoryQuizzes.explanation: The KIA works against almost everything! Whether Black plays the French (e6/d5), Sicilian (c5), or any other setup, you follow the same plan: Nf3, g3, Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2, then e4. This is what makes the KIA so special.

move.explanation: Black plays the French Defense structure with e6 and d5. This is the most common position the KIA faces.

responses.name: KIA vs French Setup
responses.description: Black sets up a French Defense with d5 and e6. The KIA is especially effective here — after Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2, and e4, White launches a powerful kingside attack.
responses.planAdjustment: Continue with Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2, then e4. Push e5 if possible to attack the Nf6 and create kingside space. This is Fischer's famous system!

move.explanation: Black plays c5, creating a Sicilian-like structure. Black fights for the queenside while you attack the kingside.

responses.name: KIA vs Sicilian Setup
responses.description: Black plays c5, leading to a reversed Sicilian structure. White's plan is still the same: complete the KIA setup and push e4.
responses.planAdjustment: Play Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2, then e4. With ...c5 on the board, Black's queen is potentially exposed on d8-h4 diagonal after e4-e5.

move.explanation: Black also fianchettos, creating the fianchetto vs fianchetto position. Both bishops fight for the long diagonal.

responses.name: KIA: Fianchetto vs Fianchetto
responses.description: Black also fianchettos with g6 and Bg7. The bishop battle on the long diagonals becomes key. White still pushes e4.
responses.planAdjustment: Continue with Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2, e4. When both sides fianchetto, your e4 push opens the position and your pieces become more active.

move.explanation: Black develops the queen's knight, keeping the position flexible without committing to a particular pawn structure.

responses.name: KIA: ...Nc6 System
responses.description: Black plays Nc6, a flexible move that keeps many options open. White continues the same KIA setup regardless.
responses.planAdjustment: Play Bg2, O-O, d3, Nbd2, then e4. Black's Nc6 doesn't change your plan — just complete your setup and push e4 when ready.
